title: 109_s2475
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Commission to Study the Potential Creation of a National Museum of the American Latino Community Act of 2006". It establishes a commission. The Commission to Study the Potential Creation of a National Museum of the American Latino Community is established with 23 members appointed by various officials. Members must have a commitment to research or study. The Commission to Study the Potential Creation of a National Museum of the American Latino Community consists of 23 members appointed by officials, with qualifications including expertise in museum administration, fundraising, Latino culture and history, and public service. The Commission to Study the Potential Creation of a National Museum of the American Latino Community requires members with expertise in museum administration, fundraising, Latino culture and history, public service, and experience in the establishment of museums focused on ethnic, racial, or cultural groups in American history. The Commission to Study the Potential Creation of a National Museum of the American Latino Community focuses on museum administration, fundraising, Latino culture and history, public service, and experience in establishing museums for ethnic, racial, or cultural groups in American history. The Commission will submit a report to the President and Congress with recommendations for establishing and maintaining a National Museum of the American Latino Community in Washington, DC. They will develop fundraising plans and examine issues such as collection availability, impact on regional museums, and possible locations for the Museum. The Commission will submit a report with recommendations for establishing a National Museum of the American Latino Community in Washington, DC. This includes examining the impact on regional museums, possible locations, governance structure, and engaging the American Latino community in the Museum's development. Legislation will be proposed to relevant House and Senate committees based on the reports submitted. The Commission will submit recommendations to relevant House and Senate committees for creating a National Museum of the American Latino Community in Washington, DC. Additionally, a national conference on the Museum will be convened within 9 months of the Act's enactment. SEC. 4. ADMINISTRATIVE PROVISIONS.

The Secretary of the Interior will provide necessary administrative services, facilities, and funds for the Commission. Members not federal employees may receive compensation and travel expenses as determined by the Secretary.

SEC. 5. DEADLINE FOR SUBMISSION OF REPORTS; TERMINATION.

The Commission must submit final reports, plans, and recommendations within 18 months of the Act's enactment. The Commission will terminate 30 days after submitting the final versions of reports. The Commission must submit final reports, plans, and recommendations within 18 months of the Act's enactment and terminate 30 days after submission. $2,100,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2007 and $1,100,000 for fiscal year 2008 for Commission activities.
